can this be closed? nature article is the final nail in the coffin in their preprint, the korean authors note one particular temperature at which lk-99’s showed a tenfold drop in resistivity, from about 0.02 ohms per centimetre to 0.002 ohms per cm. “they were very precise about it. 104.8ºc,” says prashant jain, a chemist at the university of illinois urbana–champaign. “i was like, wait a minute, i know this temperature.” the reaction that synthesizes lk-99 uses an unbalanced recipe: for every 1 part copper-doped lead phosphate crystal — pure lk-99 — it makes, it produces 17 parts copper and 5 parts sulfur. these leftovers lead to numerous impurities — especially copper sulfide, which the korean team reported in its sample. jain, a copper-sulfide expert, remembered 104ºc as the temperature at which cu2s undergoes a phase transition if exposed to air. below that temperature, cu2s’s resistivity drops dramatically — a signal almost identical to lk-99’s purported superconducting phase transition. “i was almost in disbelief that they missed it.” jain published a preprint on the important confounding effect on 7 august. [...] “that was the moment where i said, ‘well, obviously, that’s what made them think this was a superconductor,’” says fuhrer. “the nail in the coffin was this copper sulfide thing.” https://www.nature.com/articles/d41586-023-02585-7

ssc basically answered in the way i would have. the way i expect these samples to actually be measured would be as a powder, with any hypothetical 1d superconducting channels randomly oriented against the applied magnetic field. if there's a meissner effect, i expect this to result in a detectable, sharp feature around tc.  going by the opinions of experts is the  only  thing that makes sense here, as many of them have spent decades thinking about this and have much more context than any of us on what measurements have come before, what good measurements look like, what pesky failure modes to avoid, how to avoid being fooled by generic diamagnetism, non-permanent ferromagnetism and a thousand other things.

my interpretation of the meissner effect contradictions: the purity of the compound is essential for accurate detection.  small variations in what % of the synthesized bulk material is the correct phase of lead-copper apatite will lead to large variations in the observed meissner effect.  this material is likely very, very challenging for even talented synthetic chemists (and there's a lot of luck involved), hence why it took them 20-ish years to get from "okay, we have a stoichiometry and structure that we think will be scing" to "we've made this at a purity high enough to measure bulk meissner effect".  hopefully now that the recipe is online, we'll see some of the best inorganic chemists in the world try to make this thing using their own know-how, and maybe they'll make this thing at the purity levels required to get the best measurements.

well, imagine nature said anything positive, either an article or editorial. you would surely take that as a positive sign, right? so when they publish something opposite that, you must interpret that negatively. you can't have a setup where them supporting lk-99 is good and them speaking against lk-99 is meaningless.  it must be negative for them to have published a negative article.  i don't think nature would willingly let a random journalist write something like that w/out serious research and approvals internally.  within the spectrum of what they could have said, a negative editorial, approved by nature, is quite bad.  sure, not as bad as a longer article by someone more famous. but not good. same argument.  sure, it's not the  most  negative thing they could have said. but it's not very positive either.  most researchers have said they're stopping, right?  in the space of "i'm going to keep going and devote more resources" to "i'm stopping", the latter is  bad  news for lk-99.  you can't have both ends of the spectrum be good for you.  again, it's not over.  i want people to keep researching. but i do want to try to interpret new information fairly. poking holes is fine but it would have been better if the alleged lk-99 superconducting temperature were not exactly the same as the one that they were attacked for, as being from an impurity. of course, it could just be chance. but, if this really is independent, the temp would be a relatively random number.  so accidentally landing on the very temp that your impurity would mess things up at is not a good sign. will you really apply this fairly? i.e. if the editors of nature all cheered with the researchers, and were super openly positive about lk-99, do you expect me to believe you wouldn't be promoting that as evidence for yes?  i believe you would (and that would be correct). but once you admit you would accept positive sentiment, it's not reasonable to claim that negative sentiment is meaningless.  nature can 100% make mistakes...but having nature as your enemy, particularly in an abstract, scientific claim, is not overall a good thing for a theory.  again, same issue. if you would accept theoretical evidence for yes, you have to accept the lack of it as evidence for no. otherwise you've set up a logical situation where literally everything you see can be recast to support your position. why even do any research when you believe that?  but anyway, these results not being bad is a good thing for lk-99.   anyway i'm not asking for much - i hope it's real, and i hope scientists continue experimentation and theorization. luckily the ingredients and process don't seem especially difficult.  but for rigor in interpretation, we need the equivalent of pre-registration of our hypotheses. mine would be: if nature is positive about lk-99, it's good for lk-99 being real, and if they're negative, it's bad. neither is a headshot, ofc. within the space of "i found a room temp superconductor", getting the result:  lk-99 is not even an average case. this is a bad case.  good cases look like "multiple nobel prize winners fly to your lab and congratulate you, you are invited to conferences, the president of south korea personally meets you, samsung president offers to hire you and fund your lab."  none of that has happened. literally thousands of potentially convinceable people remain unconvinced, just a few miles from their lab. that must count as evidence for no.  in the space of potential rtspscs it does not  have  to be difficult to produce, or inconsistent, or obscure, or unpredictable.  the researchers don't have to be incommunicative.  it may be an accident that this is happening, but it's also consistent with no interpretations.

"we may conclude that the hybridization between the cu d-states of the cu doped with the p state of the fully occupied 1/4 occupied o1 atoms may be the key for the realization of the room temperature superconductivity" call it hopium/copium, but the original korean papers are already so immensely vague and storied in their publication, that really anything could have/have not happened, for them to have gotten the results they did. so a method that could so easily happen by accident (exposing the material to air during synthesis) may well have happened to them, and is what gave them the results they published. it could be interesting if the team from [1] re-did their analysis on the composition proposed by [2], and see if they get the 'kick' they theorise. type ii superconductors aren't repelled from magnets, they're pinned in magnetic fields. they feel a force toward wherever you last forced them to be in a magnetic field. we are yet to see anything that looks like that and i don't see it in this video. even if it can't lift its own weight, the way the rest of these things move around doesn't look like pinning, it looks like repulsion. this is what the pinning effect looks like: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=raw_ejdci0y even if we don't get a full hover, the way it moves should be more reminiscent of this this if it's a type ii superconductor. it's a restoring force toward a specific position and orientation, not merely repulsion from the magnet. type i superconductors  are  repelled and cannot levitate in a stable manner. but i don't think anyone thinks lk-99 is type i, these typically exist only at much lower temperatures than type ii superconductors. type ii is by far the more likely bet. the original lk-99 paper describes the use of annealing to produce a material with superior mechanical properties. annealing is a process that involves heating a material and then cooling it slowly. this process can be used to improve the mechanical properties of the material, such as tensile strength and hardness. the attempted replication of lk-99 at peking university used sintering rather than annealing. sintering is a process that involves heating a powdered material until the particles stick together to form a solid. this process can be used to produce complex parts with shapes that would be difficult or impossible to produce by other methods. however, sintering does not produce the same mechanical properties as annealing. in conclusion, annealing and sintering are two different materials manufacturing processes. annealing is a slower and more expensive process, but it produces a material with superior mechanical properties. sintering is a faster and cheaper process, but it does not produce the same mechanical properties as annealing.

i'm just reasoning on priors that we haven't discovered a new class of superconductor given there are only two we've discovered before, but i can't rule it out. if we do discover a room temperature sc, it's not necessary for it to be a new class, since there's nothing in our understanding to rule out room-temperature type ii scs, other than the fact we've never seen one before.  so it seems significantly more likely that we discover the first room-temperature sc and it's type ii than we discover it and  also  discover a new class of superconductor at the same time. fwiw we aren't ruling out type i because the material doesn't perfectly expel magnetic fields (i don't know if it does), we're ruling it out due to our theoretical understanding of type i superconductivity, which says they can't exist at temperatures this high. we could always be wrong about that, but also unlikely. and empirically, the hottest type i superconductors are much colder than the hottest type ii superconductors. so if we're going to find a room-temperature one, we'd be strongly expecting type ii before knowing anything else about it.
